titleStmt.title: Structural Equation Models to Interpret Multi-Trait Genome-Wide Association Studies for Morphological and Productive Traits in Soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr.]

analytic.title: Structural Equation Models to Interpret Multi-Trait Genome-Wide Association Studies for Morphological and Productive Traits in Soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr.]

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Understanding the relationship between multiple traits is fundamental in soybean breeding programs because their primary goal is to maximize multiple traits simultaneously, either directly or indirectly. Typically, multitrait studies are conducted using a multi-trait version of a genome-wide association study (GWAS). However, this approach does not account for phenotypic interrelationships between traits. Therefore, we applied structural equation modeling (SEM) to explore the interrelationship between traits related to morphology (pod thickness -PT) and yield traits (number of pods -NP, number of grains -NG, and hundred grains weight -HGW). We used a dataset containing 96 soybean individuals genotyped with 4,070 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) markers. The phenotypic network was modeled using the hill-climbing algorithm, and the structural coefficients were estimated using the SEM approach. According to the sign of the structural coefficient, we identified positive or negative phenotypic interrelationships. We found negative interrelationships between NG and HGW, positive interrelationships between NP and NG, and between HGW and PT. Among these traits, NG, HGW and PT showed indirect SNP effects. In the SEM-GWAS study, we found quantitative trait loci that jointly controlled some and all of the traits. We identified nine candidate genes (i. serine-threonine kinase; ii. protein DA1-related 2; iii. Î²-1,3-glucanase-like; iv. MYB-like DNA-binding; v. amino acid transporter; vi. Leucine-rich repeat; vii. squamosa promoter-binding-like; viii. monothiol glutaredoxin-s14, and ix. dynamin) that simultaneously acted in the traits. In summary, the SEM-GWAS approach revealed novel relationships among soybean traits, such as PT, thus contributing to soybean breeding programs. * ğ² ğğ“ * ] ğ’• is the vector of adjusted phenotypes for t traits (t = 4), ğ— ğğ , ğ— ğğ† , ğ— ğ‡ğ†ğ– and ğ— ğğ“ are the incidence matrices (only including the intercepts) for t traits; [ğ› ğğ ğ› ğğ† ğ› ğ‡ğ†ğ– ğ› ğğ“ ] ğ‘¡ is the vector of the mean effects for t traits; ğ™ ğğ , ğ™ ğğ† , ğ™ ğ‡ğ†ğ– and ğ™ ğğ“ are the incidence matrices associating ğ ğğ , ğ ğğ† , ğ ğ‡ğ†ğ– and ğ ğğ“ with ğ² ğğ * , ğ² ğğ† * , ğ² ğ‡ğ†ğ– * and ğ² ğğ“ * ; [ ğ ğğ ğ ğğ† ğ ğ‡ğ†ğ– ğ ğğ“] ğ‘¡ is the vector of additive genetic effect for t traits, and [ ğ ğğ ğ ğğ† ğ ğ‡ğ†ğ– ğ ğğ“] ğ‘¡ is the vector of model residuals for t traits. The [ ğ ğğ ğ ğğ† ğ ğ‡ğ†ğ– ğ ğğ“] ğ‘¡ and [ ğ ğğ ğ ğğ† ğ ğ‡ğ†ğ– ğ ğğ“] ğ‘¡ vectors assumed a multivariate Gaussian distribution of N(0, Î£ ğ‘” âŠ— ğ†) and N(0, Î£ ğ‘’ âŠ— ğˆ), respectively, where Î£ ğ‘” and Î£ ğ‘’ are the t Ã— t covariance matrices of additive genetic effect and model residuals, respectively, âŠ— indicates the Kronecker product, and ğ† and ğˆ are the genomic relationship matrix and the identity matrix, respectively. The ğ† matrix was estimated as G = ğ–ğ– â€² / 2 âˆ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘— (1 -m j=1

A non-informative prior was assigned to the vector of [ğ› ğğ ğ› ğğ† ğ› ğ‡ğ†ğ– ğ› ğğ“ ] ğ‘¡ . The ğšº ğ’ˆ and ğšº ğ’† matrices followed an inverse Wishart prior distribution, W t -1 (S, Î½) , where S and Î½ are hyperparameters associated to scale and degree of freedom, respectively.

The Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach was used with the Gibbs sampling algorithm to obtain marginal posterior densities. Convergence analysis was performed using the boa R package 68 . The MCMC included 3,000,000 iterations with a burn-in of 300,000 and a thinning rate of 50, yielding 54,000 MCMC samples

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Soybean is one of the five crops that dominate global agriculture, along with maize, wheat, cotton, and rice 1 . It is one of the most important commodities in global trade 2 . Brazil is the largest producer of soybeans in the world, producing 129.5 million metric tons, or about 36% of global production 1 . Soybean meal is closely linked to the food supply through direct and indirect consumption as an excellent feed supplement, especially for monogastric animals 3 . Soybean oil is highly versatile, with applications in the food and beverage, wax, construction, cosmetics, plastics, and fuel industries 4 .

Several studies using the univariate genome-wide association study (GWAS) approach have been used to identify genomic regions associated with important soybean traits, such as disease resistance [5][6][7][8] , seed protein and oil content [9][10][11][12][13] , salt tolerance 14,15 , physiological-related traits [16][17][18] , agronomic traits 10,[19][20][21][22][23][24][25] . Although the univariate GWAS methodology is the most commonly used in a breeding program, multiple correlated traits are often studied simultaneously. Another approach that allows the detection of genomic regions involved in linkage or pleiotropy is multivariate GWAS (MTM -GWAS). However, both univariate and multivariate GWAS approaches do not allow us to study the interrelationship between traits.

Given these limitations, some multivariate GWAS approaches have been developed to assess the association between traits. Shim et al. 26 proposed a methodology based on Bayes factor (mvBIMBAM). Gianola and Sorensen 27 , Momen et al. 28 , and Wang et al. 18 used structural equation in the context of GWAS (SEM-GWAS).

The SEM-GWAS approach can account for trait interactions and partition single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) effects into effects from the trait itself (direct) and from other related traits (indirect). Thus, the objectives of this study were to: (1) estimate genetic components for important traits in soybean, (2) use Bayesian network approaches to estimate a phenotypic network reflecting the interrelationship among traits, and (3) use SEM-GWAS approaches to estimate direct and indirect SNP effects.

div.head: Results
div.p: Table 1 shows the descriptive statistics (means and standard deviation) for NP, NG, HGW and PT. It was observed that, on average, the genotypes of the population presented 53.47 (Â± 11.72) pods. plant -1 , 111.40 (Â± 22.54) grains. plant -1 , 14.57 (Â± 3.04) g. 100 grains -1 and thickness of the pod with 6.41 (Â± 0.87) mm.

div.head: Genetic Parameters
div.p: Table 2 shows the narrow sense heritabilities on the diagonal, the genomic correlations on the upper triangle, and the residual correlations on the lower triangle matrix with their respective highest 95% probability density intervals (HPD) for the traits NP, NG, HGW, and PT. The narrow sense heritabilities were 0.89 (0.73, 1.00), 0.79 (0.44, 1.00), 0.39 (0.14, 0.67), and 0.45 (0.24, 0.66) for NP, NG, HGW, and PT, respectively. The genomic correlations were 0.96 (0.82, 1.00), -0.84 (-0.99, -0.55), -0.54 (-0.78, -0.28), -0.88 (-0.99, -0.

div.head: Bayesian network structure
div.p: The interrelationship between the traits is shown in Figure 1. According to the obtained phenotypic network structure, we found an arc between NP and NG with 100% strength and 58.57% direction, an arc between NG and HGW with 100% strength and 58.57% direction, and an arc between HGW and PT with 99.98% strength and 100% direction. Thus, NP was not influenced by any upstream traits, while NG was directly influenced by NP, HGW was directly influenced by NG and indirectly by NP through NG, and PT was directly influenced by HGW and indirectly by NP and NG.

div.head: Structural equation model
div.p: The estimated values of the structural coefficients represent the average increase in the downstream phenotype for a one-unit increase in the upstream phenotype (Table 4). We observed that the paths between NP and NG and between HGW and PT were positive (0.00006 and 0.00697, respectively), whereas the path between NG and HGW was negative (-0.05450). The magnitude of the estimated structural coefficient values was small, suggesting that the role of upstream traits in mediating SNP effects of downstream traits was marginal. Increasing NP, NG, and HGW by 1 unit each resulted in an average increase of 0.00006, 0.00697, and -0.05450 units in NG, HGW, and PT, respectively. Figure 2 shows the relationship between the inferred phenotypic network and the SNPs, where s j(NP) , s j(NG) , s j(HGW), and s j(PT) represent the direct effects of the SNP on NP, NG, HGW, and PT, respectively, and ğœ† 12 , ğœ† 23 , and ğœ† 34 represent the structural coefficients associated with the phenotypic network.

div.head: Partitioning of SNP effects
div.p: Figures 3 to 6 shows the effects of the SNPs decomposed into direct, indirect, and total effects for each trait using the SEM-GWAS approach.

div.head: Number of Pods (NP)
div.p: The phenotypic network did not identify any mediator trait for NP (Figure 2). In this case, the total effect of the ğ‘—th SNP on NP consists of its direct effect:
The Manhattan plots of direct (A) and total (B) SNP effects on NP are presented in Figure 3.

div.head: Number of Grains (NG)
div.p: In addition to the direct effect of the ğ‘—th SNP associated with NG, there was an indirect effect mediated by NP (ğœ† 12 = 0.00006). Thus, the total effect was calculated by summing the direct and indirect effects. The Manhattan plots of direct (A), indirect (B), and total (C) SNP effects on NG are presented in Figure 4. The Manhattan plots of direct (A), indirect (B), and total (C) SNP effects on HGW are presented in Figure 5.

div.head: Pod Thickness (PT)
div.p: The overall effect of the SNP on PT was decomposed into a direct effect and three indirect effects mediated by HGW, NG, and NP. The structural coefficients for the indirect effects were ğœ† 34 (0.0018) for HGW, The Manhattan plots of direct (A), indirect (B), and total (C) SNP effects on PT are presented in Figure 6.

div.head: Structural equation modeling associated to genome-wide association study (SEM-GWAS)
div.p: In total, 46 SNP were statistically significant (q-value < 0.01) for the traits studied (Table S5). Of those, 36, 36, and 20 SNP were associated with NP, NG, and HGW, respectively. No significant SNP was found for PT.
For NP, we found significant SNP on chromosomes

div.head: Genetic parameters
div.p: All genomic correlations were significant, whereas only the residual correlation between HGW and PT was significant according to HPD. The narrow sense heritability estimates were moderate to high for NP (0.89Â±0.09), NG (0.79Â±0.18), HGW (0.39Â±0.14), and PT (0.45Â±0.11).

The heritability estimates for NP and NG were similar to those found in the literature. Our heritability estimate for HGW differed from the literature, possibly because we used a different estimation method. No heritability results were found in the literature for PT. According to Aditya et al. 29 , using a database of 31 genotypes of G. max (L.) Merrill, a heritability estimate of 0.81 was found for NP. Ghiday et al. 30 , using 22 promising genotypes from IITA/Nigeria, found a heritability estimate of 0.93 for NP. Del Conte et al. 31 , using 34 ğ¹ 1 soybean populations in a path analysis, found a heritability for NP of 0.83. For NG, Ghiday et al. 30 reported a heritability of 0.98. Similarly, Del Conte et al. 31 and de Albuquerque et al. 32 reported heritability estimates of 0.70 and 0.59, respectively. For HGW, Bisinotto et al. 33 , reported a heritability estimate of 0.77 using 31 lines from a breeding program.

The genomic correlation estimates were consistent with those found in the literature. According to Del Conte et al. 31 and Li et al. 34 , the genetic correlation estimates between NP and NG were 0.87 and 0.88, respectively.
Li et al. 34 reported genetic correlations of -0.25 and -0.29 between NP and HGW, and NG and HGW, respectively.

Silva et al. 35 found a correlation of -0.95 between NG and HGW. The signs of the correlations were identical to those found in this work. However, their estimates differed in magnitude, which could be due to the population and environmental differences from the data in this work. No study was found that showed a correlation with PT.

div.head: Structural equation modeling associated to genome-wide association study
div.p: Currently, the opening of immature pods (opening of still green pods and grains in the filling stage) causes production losses in a large area of Brazil and the world. Palharini 36 reported that such an event is related to the genotypes used and water deficit. In view of this finding, a Bayesian network was modeled, showing the links between the phenotypes (NP, NG, and HGW) favorable and unfavorable to PT, related to the susceptibility to pod opening. The structure of the phenotypic network was incorporated into the SEM-based GWAS model to decompose SNP effects into direct effects on the trait and trait-mediated effects upstream in the phenotypic network.
The effects of the markers partitioned into direct and indirect effects were obtained using SEM-GWAS.

Our results showed that there was a positive direct effect from NP to NG and HGW to PT, and the indirect from NP to HGW and PT, NG to HGW and NG to PT. The positive interrelationships indicate that the greater the number of pods, the greater the number of grains Also, the greater the weight of a thousand grains, the greater the thickness of the pod. In contrast, the negative interrelationships indicate that the greater the number of grains, the lower the weight of a thousand grains.

In general, our results suggested that the direct effects of SNPs were greater than the indirect effects for NG and PT. However, we observed that HGW showed a large indirect effect coming from NG (Table 4), indicating that the total effects of SNPs associated with HGW were moderately influenced by the indirect effect coming from NG. We also observed that some QTLs controlled more than one trait, which is indicative of multiple functionality (Table S5). Other studies in the literature also identified QTLs controlling more than one trait in soybean 12,22 and rice 37 , however, other works did not identify such multifunctionality of QTLs 38 .

The functions of 46 candidate genes for NP, NG and HGW were investigated. Among these, some candidate genes control the traits simultaneously. The candidate's genes were highlighted below with their identification, functional annotation and related characteristics (Table S5): i. Glyma.01G052600 -serine-threonine protein kinase (NP, NG and HGW); ii. Glyma.02G251800 -protein DA1-related 2 (NP); iii. Glyma.02G253800Î²-1,3-glucanase-like protein (NP); iv. Glyma.03G183900 -MYB-like DNA-binding protein MYB (NG and HGW); v. Glyma.04G086600 -amino acid transporter (NP); vi. Glyma.04G239000 -leucine rich repeat (lrr_1) // protein tyrosine kinase (pkinase_tyr) // leucine rich repeat n-terminal domain (lrrnt_2) // leucine rich repeat (lrr_8) (NP, NG and HGW); vii. Glyma.05G019000 -squamosa promoter-binding-like protein 15-related (NP); viii.

Glyma.09G252200 -monothiol glutaredoxin-s14, chloroplastic (NG and HGW) and ix. Glyma.12G242300dynamin (NP and NG). According to Liu et al. 39 , serine-threonine protein kinase is involved in the plant response to a variety of abiotic stresses. Thus, the production efficiency of plants under stress is increased. For protein DA1related 2, Zhao et al. 40 reported that the candidate gene is functionally associated with the adaptive radiation of soybeans. Using Arabidopsis, Li et al. 41 characterized DA1 as a ubiquitin receptor, having features such as a wide range of cellular processes 42 and biological processes, such as abnormal protein degradation 43,44 , hormonal signaling 45,46 , resistance to disease and abiotic stresses 45,47,48 , and cell cycles 49 . According to Balasubramanianet al. 50 , Î² -1,3-glucanases group of proteins is expressed in plants to withstand abiotic stresses, generally with respect to their expression during pathogen infection and their broadspectrum antimicrobial activity. Callose, a 1,3-Î²glucan which is a common substrate of 1,3-Î²-glucanase, is reversibly and transiently deposited in plant cell walls as part of the hypersensitive response to fungi, viruses, and abiotic stresses 51,52 . For MYB-like DNA-binding protein MYB, Du et al. 53 reported that members of this large gene family may be involved in different plant biological processes, some of which may be potentially involved in legume-specific nodulation. Another function of a listed candidate gene was the amino acid transporter. Cheng et al. 54 , using soybean, identified that this transporter plays an important role in transporting amino acids across cellular membranes and is essential for plant growth and development. In genome-wide analysis using soybean, Zhou et al. 55 found that leucine rich repeat constitutes the largest subfamily of receptor-like kinases in the plant. A number of reports have demonstrated that plant LRR-RLKs play important roles in growth, development, differentiation, and stress responses. Squamosa promoter-binding-like protein was reported by several studies [56][57][58][59][60][61][62] . In these studies, the authors identified a broad range of plant biological processes, such as the timing of vegetative phase changes and floral induction, the rate of leaf initiation, shoot regeneration and branching, anthocyanin and trichome production, stress responses, carotenoid biosynthesis, and lateral root development. Monothiol glutaredoxin is known to catalyze the reversible reduction of disulfide bonds utilizing the reducing power of glutathione (GSH) and NADPH-dependent glutathione reductase (GR) and have a role in maintaining and regulating cellular redox homeostasis 63 . Finally, regarding the last candidate gene that presents dynamin function, Diers et al. 64 found the same candidate gene (GLYMA.12G242300), which is related to growth and development 65 .

This study used SEM-GWAS to show that most of the genetic effects are the result of the direct effect of the SNP. However, for HGW, we observed a moderate contribution of genetic effects from the SNP influencing NG. Our approach allowed us to better understand the complexity in terms of the interrelationship between the traits. Associating the results to a breeding program scenario, we can see that understanding the existing interrelationships in the trait network makes it possible to outline selection strategies more efficiently, which may result in increases in the gain from selection. In the case of a large direct effect and low correlation between traits, there is an indication that simultaneous selection is the best strategy to use. Also, when there is a large direct effect and a high correlation between traits, there is an indication that indirect selection should be advocated, because most variation in the other trait is determined by the trait in question.

In conclusion, this was the first work showing an application and the potential of SEM-GWAS in soybean, where it was possible to partition the effects of SNP markers for NP, NG, HGW and PT, and also to identify QTLs with their respective functionalities.

div.head: Phenotypic data and SNP genotyping
div.p: The phenotypic and genotypic data were collected from the soybean breeding program of the Federal University of ViÃ§osa (in Portuguese, Universidade Federal de ViÃ§osa -UFV). Two experiments were conducted in a greenhouse located in the city of ViÃ§osa -MG (Brazil) (lat. 20Â°45â€²17" S lat; long. 42Â°52â€²57" W long). The experiment was planted from January to May 2018. The design used was randomized blocks, with 96 soybean genotypes evaluated in 3 blocks. The genotypes evaluated were from different soybean genetic improvement companies with a wide variation in their traits, including different transgenic events (conventional, Roundup Ready, and Intacta RR2BT), growth types (determinate, semi-determinate, and indeterminate), and maturity groups (five to nine). The percentage of open immature pods per plant was evaluated at the R6 development stage (green pods with full kernels) based on the total number of pods. Four traits were evaluated in this work: NPnumber of pods (pods. plant -1 ), NG -number of grains (grains. plant -1 ), HGW -hundred grains weight (g), and

PTpod thickness (mm). The SNP quality control parameters used were call rate (â‰¥ 95%) and minor allele frequency (< 5%). Genotyping data of the genotypes were provided by GDM Seeds. Eighty-one and eighteen genotypes were genotyped via genotyping by sequencing at the Institute for Genome Diversity at Cornell University (Ithaca, NY) and the Biotechnology Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison (Wisconsin, USA), respectively 66 .

div.head: Phenotypic data analysis
div.p: Prior to GWAS, the phenotypic values were adjusted for systematic effects according to the following statistical model:

where ğ² is the vector of observed phenotypes, ğ® and ğ« are the vectors of overall mean (fixed effect) and between block effect (fixed effect), respectively, ğ and ğ are the vectors of genotypic effects (random effect) and model residuals (random effect), respectively. ğ—, ğ™ and ğ– are the incidence matrices relating ğ®, g and r, respectively. S1 andS3) and Geweke tests (Tables S2 andS4).

div.head: Bayesian networks
div.p: The Bayesian Network (BN) was used to assess the relationships between the traits. A Bayesian network can be viewed as a graphical model based on a directed acyclic graph, where nodes (or vertices) represent random variables and arcs (or edges) represent probabilistic dependencies between them 69,70 . In general, a directed acyclic graph is formed by nodes connected by directed edges, where the probability that an edge exists between nodes (strength) and the probability that the edge has a particular direction (direction) can be estimated.

The Hill Climbing (HC) algorithm, implemented in the bnlearn R package 71 was used to estimate a phenotypic network. The HC algorithm finds the best structure of the network by removing arcs and changing their directions. For each edge removal, the Bayesian Information Criteria (BIC) was computed to infer its relative contribution to the overall BIC of the network. A total of 50,000 bootstrap samples were used to define the strength and direction of each arc. We used the criteria of direction > 50% and strength â‰¥ 80% to select high-confidence relationships.

div.head: Multi-trait association analysis (MTM-GWAS)
div.p: MTM-GWAS modeling was performed using the SNP Snappy strategy 72 74 . The SNP dosage matrix has also been corrected for the population structure, where 23 principal components were used, resulting in approximately 80% of the genetic variability.

div.head: Structural equations modeling GWAS (SEM-GWAS)
div.p: SEM-GWAS partitions the total SNP effect into direct and indirect effects using an inferred phenotypic network structure. SEM-GWAS was performed using the SNP Snappy strategy 72 . More details on the SEM-GWAS procedure can be found in Suela et al. 38 .

ğ² * = ğš²ğ² * + ğ–ğ¬ + ğ™ğ + ğ, The structural equations to estimate the direct and indirect effects of the SNP for the four traits, based on the phenotypic interrelationships previously estimated by the Bayesian network were: The indirect effect of a SNP on a trait was estimated by multiplying the direct effect of the SNP on the trait by the structural coefficient associated with the path between the two traits 28,37 .

div.head: Pathway enrichment analyses
div.p: We selected the relevant SNPs using the p-value (<0.01) obtained from MTM-GWAS (no window size was used). We used the Glycine max genomic database available at Phytozome 75 (https://phytozome-next.jgi.doe.gov/jbrowse/index.html?data=genomes%2FGmax_Wm82_a2_v1&loc=Chr01%3A5673531..511388 29&tracks=Transcripts%2CAlt_Transcripts%2CPASA_assembly%2CBlastx_protein%2CBlatx_Fabidae%2CBl atx_BasalEmbryophyte%2CBlatx_BasalMalvidae&highlight=) to assess the functionality of each identified gene and the enriched gene ontology (GO) terms.

figure.figDesc: Figures7 and 8show the results of the pathway enrichment analysis using GO. For NP, relevant GO terms identified include inactive shikimate kinase, serine-threonine protein kinase, Gdt1-like protein, polyglutamine-binding, protein da1-related 2, Î²-1, 3-glucanase-like protein, DNAj homolog, fructosebisphosphate aldolase, Amino acid transporter, protein tyrosine kinase, squamosa promoter-binding, xenobiotic monooxygenase, reverse transcriptase, RNA-binding proprotein convertase subtilisin, NADPH oxidase, DNA mismatch repair, Acyl-CoA n-acyltransferase, dynamin, small heat-shock, ribosomal biogenesis, acylglycerol lipase, snare, phosphatase, u3 small nucleolar, ap-4 complex, ABC transporter, ww domain, proprotein convertase, hnh endonuclease. For NG, relevant GO terms identified include Inactive shikimate kinase, Myb-like DNAbinding, glycine-rich protein, ubiquitin carboxyl-terminal hydrolase, ABC transporter, dentin sialophosphoprotein, threonine-protein kinase srk-related, monothiol glutaredoxin, and mono-ADP-ribosyltransferase.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: This work was financially supported by the Foundation for Research Support of the state of Minas Gerais (FAPEMIG), by the National Council of Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq), and by the National 23 Institutes of Science and Technology of Coffee (INCT/CafÃ©). MMS, MN and CFA is supported by a doctorate's scholarships (140877/2021-5) and scientific productivity (307798/2019-4 and 306772/2020-5), respectively, from Brazilian Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq).

div.head: Data Archiving Statement
div.p: The authors have not submitted biological data to any of the public databases.

div.head: Data availability
div.p: The datasets generated during and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

div.head: Author contributions
div.p: Conceptualization

div.head: Competing interests
div.p: The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest.
